article.paragraph: Aage Niels Bohr(IPA-daˈɔːʊ̯ə ˌnels ˈboɐ̯ˀlangDa-Aage Niels Bohr.ogg; 19 June 1922 9 September 2009) was a Danishnuclear physicsnuclear physicistwho shared theNobel Prize in Physicsin 1975 withBen MottelsonandJames Rainwater"for the discovery of the connection between collective motion and particle motion inatomic nucleiand the development of the theory of the structure of the atomic nucleus based on this connection".cite webhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1975/The Nobel Prize in Physics 1975The Nobel Foundation12 May 2015Starting from Rainwater's concept of an irregular-shapedSemi-empirical mass formula#The liquid drop model and its analysisliquid drop modelof the nucleus, Bohr and Mottelson developed a detailed theory that was in close agreement with experiments. Since his father,Niels Bohr, had won the prize in 1922, he is one of four pairs of fathers and sons who have won the Nobel Prize in Physics.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Aage Niels Bohr was born inCopenhagenon 19 June 1922, the fourth of six sons of thephysicistNiels Bohrand his wife Margrethe Bohr (ne Nrlund).cite webhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1975/bohr-bio.htmlAage N. Bohr – BiographicalThe Nobel Foundation12 May 2015His oldest brother, Christian, died in a boating accident in 1934,sfnStuewer1985204and his youngest, Harald, from childhood meningitis.sfnPais1991226, 249Of the others, Hans became a physician; Erik, a chemical engineer; andErnest BohrErnest, a lawyer and an Olympic athlete who playedfield hockeyfor Denmark at the1948 Summer Olympicsin London.cite webNiels Bohr – Biographyhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1922/bohr-bio.html[[Nobelprize.org]]10 November 2011cite webhttp://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/bo/ernest-bohr-1.htmlErnest Bohr Biography and Olympic Results – OlympicsSports-Reference.com12 February 2013The family lived at the Institute of Theoretical Physics at theUniversity of Copenhagen, now known as theNiels Bohr Institute, where he grew up surrounded by physicists who were working with his father, such asHans Kramers,Oskar Klein,Yoshio Nishina,Wolfgang PauliandWerner Heisenberg.In 1932, the family moved to the Carlsberg resbolig, a mansion donated byCarl Jacobsen, the heir to Carlsberg breweries, to be used as an honorary residence by the Dane who had made the most prominent contribution to science, literature or the arts.sfnPais1991322–333

Bohr was educated at theilldaSortedam Gymnasiumin Copenhagen. In 1940, shortly after the April German occupation of Denmark, he entered the University of Copenhagen, where he studied physics. He assisted his father, helping draft correspondence and articles related toepistemologyand physics.In September 1943, word reached his family that the Nazis considered it to be Jewish, since Aage's grandmother, Ellen Adler Bohr, had been Jewish, and that they were in danger of being arrested. The Danish resistance helped the familyRescue of the Danish Jewsescape by seato Sweden.sfnRhodes1986483–484Bohr arrived there in October 1943, and then flew to Britain on ade Havilland Mosquitooperated byBritish Overseas Airways Corporation. The Mosquitoes were unarmed high-speed bomber aircraft that had been converted to carry small, valuable cargoes or important passengers. By flying at high speed and high altitude, they could cross German-occupied Norway, and yet avoid German fighters. Bohr, equipped with parachute, flying suit and oxygen mask, spent the three-hour flight lying on a mattress in the aircraft'sbomb bay.sfnJones1985280

On arrival in London, Bohr rejoined his father, who had flown to Britain the week before.sfnJones1985280He officially became a junior researcher at theDepartment of Scientific and Industrial Research (United Kingdom)Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, but actually served as personal assistant and secretary to his father. The two worked onTube Alloys, the Britishatomic bombproject. On 30 December 1943, they made the first of a number of visits to the United States, where his father was a consultant toManhattan Project.sfnGowing1964248–249Due to his father's fame, they were given false names; Bohr became James Baker, and his father, Nicholas Baker.sfnHoddesonHenriksenMeadeWestfall199395In 1945, the director of theLos Alamos Laboratory,Robert Oppenheimer, asked them to review the design of themodulated neutron initiator. They reported that it would work. That they had reached this conclusion putEnrico Fermi's concerns about the viability of the design to rest.sfnHoddesonHenriksenMeadeWestfall199395The initiators performed flawlessly in the bombs used in theatomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasakiin August 1945.sfnHoddesonHenriksenMeadeWestfall1993264–265, 308–309, 390–397
article.heading: Physics
article.paragraph: In August 1945, with the war ended, Bohr returned to Denmark, where he resumed his university education, graduating with a master's degree in 1946, with a thesis concerned with some aspects ofStopping power (particle radiation)atomic stopping powerproblems.In early 1948, Bohr became a member of theInstitute for Advanced StudyinPrinceton, New Jersey.cite webhttp://www.ias.edu/people/cos/users/abohr01Bohr, Aage Niels[[Institute for Advanced Study]]13 May 2015While paying a visit toColumbia University, he metIsidor Isaac Rabi, who sparked an interest in recent discoveries related to thehyperfine structureofdeuterium. This led to Bohr becoming a visiting fellow at Columbia from January 1949 to August 1950.While in the United States, Bohr married Marietta Soffer on 11 March 1950. They had three children: Vilhelm, Tomas and Margrethe.cite news[[New York Times]]http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/world/europe/11bohr.htmlAage Bohr, Physicist’s Son Who Won Nobel, Dies at 87KennethChang10 September 2009cite webhttp://www.geni.com/people/Marietta-Bohr/6000000009135398187Marietta Bohr (Soffer) (1922–1978)Geni.com14 May 2015

By the late 1940s it was known that the properties ofatomic nucleicould not be explained by the then-current models such as theSemi-empirical mass formula#The liquid drop model and its analysisliquid drop modeldeveloped by Niels Bohr amongst others. TheNuclear shell modelshell model, developed in 1949 byMaria Goeppert-Mayerand others, allowed some additional features to be explained, in particular the so-calledMagic number (physics)magic numbers. However, there were also properties which could not be explained, including the non-spherical distribution of charge in certain nuclei.cite webRotational Motion in Nuclei Nobel Lecture,11 December 1975AageBohrThe Niels Bohr Institute and NorditaCopenhagenhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1975/bohr-lecture.pdf14 May 2015In a 1950 paper,James Rainwaterof Columbia University suggested a variant of the drop model of the nucleus which could explain a non-spherical charge distribution.cite journalNuclear Energy Level Argument for a Spheroidal Nuclear ModelRainwaterJamesJames Rainwater[[Physical Review]]793432–434August 1950American Physical Society10.1103/PhysRev.79.4321950PhRv...79..432RRainwater's model postulated a nucleus like a balloon with balls inside, which distorted the surface as they moved about. He discussed the idea with Bohr, who was visiting Columbia at the time, and had independently conceived the same idea, and had submitted a paper for publication about a month after Rainwater's, which discussed the same problem, but along more general lines. Bohr imagined a rotating, irregular-shaped nucleus with a form of surface tension.cite journal[[New Scientist]]0262-40796897223 October 1975Nobel Prizes 1975: Medicine, Chemistry and Physics … and fifty years agoRogerLewinMartinSherwoodRobertWalgateBohr developed the idea further, in 1951 publishing a paper which comprehensively treated the relationship between oscillations of the surface of the nucleus and the movement of the individualnucleons.cite journalOn the Quantization of Angular Momenta in Heavy NucleiBohrAage[[Physical Review]]811134–138January 1951American Physical Society10.1103/PhysRev.81.1341951PhRv...81..134B

On his return to Copenhagen in 1950, Bohr began working withBen Mottelsonto compare the theoretical work with experimental data. In three papers that were published in 1952 and 1953, Bohr and Mottelson demonstrated close agreement between theory and experiment; for example, showing that the energy levels of certain nuclei could be described by a rotation spectrum.cite journal[[Det Kongelige Danske Videnskabernes Selskab]]Collective and Individual-Particle Aspects of Nuclear Structure2761953BohrAageMottelsonBen R.Ben Mottelsonhttp://www.sdu.dk/media/bibpdf/Bind%2020-29%5CBind%5Cmfm-27-16.pdf14 May 2015cite journalInterpretation of Isomeric Transitions of Electric Quadrupole TypeBohrAageMottelsonBen R.Ben Mottelson[[Physical Review]]891316–317January 1953American Physical Society10.1103/PhysRev.89.3161953PhRv...89..316Bcite journalRotational States in Even-Even NucleiBohrAageMottelsonBen R.Ben Mottelson[[Physical Review]]904717–719May 1953American Physical Society10.1103/PhysRev.90.717.21953PhRv...90..717BThey were thereby able to reconcile the shell model with Rainwater's concept.This work stimulated many new theoretical and experimental studies.Bohr, Mottelson and Rainwater were jointly awarded the 1975Nobel Prize in Physics"for the discovery of the connection between collective motion and particle motion in atomic nuclei and the development of the theory of the structure of the atomic nucleus based on this connection".Since his father had been awarded the prize in 1922, Bohr became one of only four pairs of fathers and sons to win the Nobel Prize in Physics.cite webhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/facts/physics/Facts on the Nobel Prizes in PhysicsThe Nobel Foundation12 May 2015The others:William Henry Bragg(1915) andWilliam Lawrence Bragg(1915);J. J. Thomson(1906) andGeorge Paget Thomson(1937); andManne Siegbahn(1924) andKai M. Siegbahn(1981). Two pairs of fathers and sons have won Nobel Prizes in other fields:Hans von Euler-Chelpin(chemistry, 1929) andUlf von Euler(medicine, 1970); andArthur Kornberg(medicine, 1969) andRoger D. Kornberg(chemistry, 2006).He married Marietta Soffer in 1950. They had two sons, Vilhelm and Tomas, and a daughter, Margrethe.cite news[[Los Angeles Times]]Aage Bohr dies at 87; Danish physicist and Nobel Prize winnerThomas H. IIMaugh18 September 2009http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-me-aage-bohr18-2009sep18-story.html12 September 2015

Only after doing his Nobel Prize-winning research did Bohr receive his doctorate from the University of Copenhagen, in 1954, writing his thesis on "Rotational States of Atomic Nuclei".cite webhttp://clio.columbia.edu/catalog/1565671Rotational States of Atomic Nuclei[[Columbia University]]195414 May 2015Bohr became a professor at the University of Copenhagen in 1956, and, following his father's death in 1962, succeeded him as director of the Niels Bohr Institute, a position he held until 1970. He remained active there until he retired in 1992.He was also a member of the board of theNordic Institute for Theoretical Physics(Nordita) from its inception in 1957, and was its director from 1975 to 1981.cite webhttp://www.nbi.ku.dk/english/namely_names/2009/nobel_prize_recipient_aage_bohr/Nobel Laureate Aage Bohr has died[[Niels Bohr Institute]]14 May 2015In addition to the Nobel Prize, he won theDannie Heineman Prize for Mathematical Physicsin 1960, theAtoms for Peace Awardin 1969,H.C. rsted Medalin 1970,Rutherford Medal and Prizein 1972,John Price Wetherill Medalin 1974, and the Ole Rmer medal in 1976.cite webhttp://www.casinapioiv.va/content/accademia/en/academicians/deceased/bohr.htmlAntoninoZichichiAntonino ZichichiAage Bohr[[Pontifical Academy of Sciences]]30 May 2012cite webhttps://www.iop.org/about/awards/subject/rutherford/medallists/page_38596.htmlRutherford medal recipients[[Institute of Physics]]14 May 2015Bohr and Mottelson continued to work together, publishing a two-volumemonograph,Nuclear Structure. The first volume,Single-Particle Motion,appeared in 1969; the second,Nuclear Deformations,in 1975.

In 1972 he was awarded anhonorary degree, doctor philos. honoris causa, at theNorwegian Institute of Technology, later part ofNorwegian University of Science and Technology.cite webhttp://www.ntnu.edu/phd/honorary-doctorsHonorary doctors at NTNUNorwegian University of Science and TechnologyEnglish

His wife Marietta died on 2 October 1978.In 1981, he married Bente Scharff Meyer.cite news[[The Guardian]]FrankClose14 September 2009Aage Bohrhttp://www.theguardian.com/science/2009/sep/13/aage-bohr-obituary12 September 2015His son, Tomas Bohr, is a Professor of Physics at theTechnical University of Denmark, working in the area of fluid dynamics.cite webhttp://www.dtu.dk/english/Service/Phonebook/Person?idTomas Bohr[[Technical University of Denmark]]14 May 2015Aage Bohr died in Copenhagen on 9 September 2009.cite newshttp://politiken.dk/videnskab/article785607.eceNobelprisvinderen Aage Bohr er død ("Nobel Prize winner Aage Bohr has died")VidenMorten GarlyAndersonDanish10 September 2009He was survived by his second wife and children.
